The Ran space

Feb 5, 2020

Let be a topological space. We can then imagine that there is a pre-cosheaf on the space (denoted ) of finite subsets whose stalk at the point corresponding to is . There is a noncanonical homotopy equivalence . The multiplication on which makes it into an -algebra in pointed spaces suggests that “colliding points” leads to a sort of multiplicative structure on this pre-cosheaf.

This argument can be made precise: there is an equivalence of categories between -algebras in a symmetric monoidal category and “factorizable -valued cosheaves” on the Ran-space . This is stated in Theorem 5.5.4.10 of Higher Algebra. (Note that the global sections of the factorizable cosheaf associated to an -algebra is precisely its -topological Hochschild homology.) Let’s understand this more precisely.

If is a manifold, then is the space of finite nonempty subsets of . The topology on is generated as follows: let ; then let . Let be given the topology generated by the sets , where the s are pairwise disjoint open subsets of . Beilinson and Drinfeld showed that if is connected, then is contractible. (There’s another topology we could give . First, we can filter by the cardinality of subsets. Call the stages in this filtration , and equip these with the subspace topology. Now declare to be open iff is open for all .)

Let denote the poset of opens of . Then a -valued cosheaf on is a functor such that for each , the functor is a sheaf. Say that is constructible if is an equivalence, where , and the restriction to each is locally constant (i.e., the usual definition of constructibility). Further say that is factorizable if it is constructible, and when and are disjoint opens in . This gives us all the terms needed to make sense of the equivalence of categories stated in the beginning.

One important special case of this equivalence of categories is in the case : the statement is then that , where the stands for constructible, and the for factorizable. The observation is that this might be helpful in defining -algebras in the motivic setting. In particular, one big problem in the unstable motivic world is -loop space recognition. One might hope that the Ran-space approach works motivically to get some kind of recognition principle.

The replacement for would be the Ran-space : this can be defined as the presheaf assigning to a -algebra the set of nonempty finite subsets of over . The ultra-typical example of what should be an -algebra in the motivic setting is the Beilinson-Drinfeld Grassmannian. If is a reductive group, this is the presheaf sending a -algebra to the set of -torsors on equipped with a trivialization away from a chosen . There is a canonical map , and the fiber over a -point is noncanonically isomorphic to a product of copies of the -points of the affine Grassmannian . The Beilinson-Drinfeld Grassmannian should somehow be the total space of a “factorizable cosheaf” over .

What exactly that’s supposed to mean seems to be up for grabs. We also don’t need to work over for any of this.

If is a motivic space, one could nonetheless define another candidate for a factorizable cosheaf over : let denote the presheaf sending a -algebra to the set of pairs , where , and is a map in the unstable motivic category. The motivic space can be identified with , and is noncanonically the same as a wedge of copies of .

Here are some questions I would like to think about:

  • What is a factorizable cosheaf over the algebro-geometric Ran-space ? In the topological world, is there some characterization of the total spaces of factorizable cosheaves which can be transferred to the algebro-geometric setting?
  • Is an example of such a factorizable cosheaf? (It must be!)
  • Is the zeroth space of a -module (motivically) a factorizable cosheaf?
  • In the topological world, where does the Dyer-Lashof operation show up from the point of view of the Ran space? Can the construction that produces this operation be mimicked in the algebro-geometric setting?

It’s rather interesting to me that -motivic and -equivariant homotopy theory seem to most naturally have double loop spaces flying all over the place (rather than single loop spaces), and that this is the same structure that’s showing up in this Hopkins-Mahowald Thom spectrum project that I’m (mostly done) writing up. Maybe that’s just a coincidence.
